title: when the ambulance drove off little did we know there would be no contact with her again
story: When Jemima George died from Covid, her daughter Roberta could not attend the funeral as she too was battling the virusExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseJemima George is fondly remembered as the heart and soul of her family FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueJemima George is fondly remembered as the heart and soul of her familyLisa SmythTwitterMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailJEMIMA George was the heart and soul of her family.Covid- robbed them of a beloved great grandmother. It even snatched away their chance to say a proper goodbye to her.The depth of her family’s grief made headlines earlier this year. Her son-in-law, DUP MP Jim Shannon, challenged Boris Johnson over the lockdown parties at  Downing Street which took place at the same time Ms George , from Newtownards, Co Down, lost her le to the virus in October .“She was so devoted to her family, she lived for her family,” said Mr Shannon.“Birthdays, anniversaries, she never forgot any of them. Christmas was particularly special, and even though she and my father-in-law Robert were pensioners, all their savings would go to the family.“She would have saved up all her coppers, silvers and pounds in a jar and there would be money for everyone at Christmas.Ms George was moved from the emergency department at the Ulster Hospital on the outskirts of east Belfast to a ward where her daughter, Roberta, was also being treated for Covid.Mr Shannon continued: “Roberta couldn’t even go and see her mum even though they were in the same ward.“She was admitted to the hospital on Monday and died on Friday.“It was the horrible and cruel way that she was taken away from us [that hurt so much]. When the ambulance drove off, little did we know there would be no contact with her again.“Roberta couldn’t even go to the funeral because she was still in hospital fighting for her le.“Sandra was left to organise everything because Roberta was so sick. She had to even choose what family and friends could attend the funeral because we were only allowed to have  people there.“That is one thing that has grieved me greatly – how do you draw up a guest Photo: Stock image FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueConnected Health provides home care workers to all five trusts in Northern Ireland. Photo: Stock imageCiaran O#NeillMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA company which has been paid almost £m recently by Northern Ireland health trusts has received three public notices in the past year about being struck off.Connected Health provides home care workers for all five health trusts in Northern Ireland.New figures show the company has been paid £.m by the trusts in the last two financial years.However, the Sunday Independent has learned that in the past year, the company has received three compulsory strike-off notices from Companies House, which is the regulatory body responsible for the registration of businesses in the UK.All three notices were subsequently “discontinued”.According to Companies House, a business will receive a compulsory strike-off noticeCompanies House has “reasonable cause” to believe the company is not carrying on its business or is no longer in operation.The registrar may take this view for a number of reasons, such as, it has not received company documents that should have been sent to it, or letters the registrar has sent to a company’s registered office are ed undelivered.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Before striking a company off the register, Companies House is required to write two formal letters and send a notice to the company’s registered office to inquire whether it is still operating.If Companies House is satisfied that the business is not operating, it will publish a notice in the Gazette publication, which includes information on every company registered in the UK, stating their intention to strike the company off the register unless they are shown reason not to do so.If a company is struck off by Companies House, it is no longer allowed to trade and its assets become the property of the Crown.Connected Health, whose headquarters are in Belfast but which also has offices in the Republic and England, is made up of two separate companies, a holding company called Connected Health Limited and an operating company called Connected Health Domiciliary Care Limited.Compulsory strike-off notices in relation to Connected Health Limited were published in the Gazette on April , , and March , .Both strike-off actions were subsequently “discontinued” on May , , and March ,  respectively, according to the company’s details on the Companies House website.Another compulsory strike notice in connection with Connected Health Domiciliary Care Limited was published in the Gazette on March  this year but “discontinued” two days later.A Companies House spokesperson said they did not comment on the reasons for the issuing of strike-off notices to inidual businesses.However, a spokesperson for Connected Health, which was set up in  and describes itself as “one of the leading domiciliary care providers in Northern Ireland, Great Britain and the ROI”, said the strike-off notices it received were “computer generated, as per standard procedure, by Companies House because the financial accounts were technically overdue, despite an extension being granted by HMRC”.“The delays were due to finance department staffing pressures at Connected Health, including the long-term illness of our financial controller, multiple Covid-related isolations and the rapid growth in care staff to address the unprecedented healthcare crisis,” the spokesperson said.“Amid this perfect storm, our priority was managing payroll to ensure our carers were rewarded for their dedication and bravery in what was a very dficult period for frontline healthcare generally. “We did all this while maximising efforts to protect both our vulnerable clients and our committed staff at the height of the Covid- pandemic.“Once issued, the notices were rightfully retracted within a number of days.”The Connected Health spokesperson stressed that the company is in a “strong and robust financial position”. They said they were experiencing “signicant growth year-on-year” as they continue to provide “award-winning care to our partners in the Northern Ireland trusts, and also in Great Britain and the Republic of Ireland”.“For clarity, the total profit for Connected Health in Northern Ireland for the year to December  was £.m on a turnover of £.m, with total net assets of £.m,” the spokesperson added.“There are signicant growth plans for Connected Health in . We are creating , new jobs on the island of Ireland this year. Recruitment is progressing as planned, with  new care posts in Northern Ireland and another  in the Republic of Ireland.”The figures paid by the five health trusts to Connected Health in the last two years emerged recently following a question at the Northern Ireland Assembly by People Before Profit MLA Gerry Carroll. He asked for details of the funding provided to the company by the Department of Health.In response, Health Minister Robin Swann said his department did not provide funding directly to Connected Health but that the five health trusts in Northern Ireland paid the company for the delivery of services in relation to domiciliary care.Mr Swann stated that the total amounts paid to Connected Health in the   financial year and the   financial year to date by each of the trusts were: Belfast Health and Social Care TrustSouth Eastern Health and Social Care TrustNorthern Health and Social Care title: sdlps colum eastwood leaves opposition on the table depending on negotiations following stormont assembly election
story: SDLP MP Colum Eastwood. Credit: Colm Lenaghan Pacemaker FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSDLP MP Colum Eastwood. Credit: Colm Lenaghan PacemakerChristopher LeebodyTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThe SDLP “want to be in government” following the upcoming Assembly Election but opposition is still an option “on the table”, according to leader Colum Eastwood.Speaking on the BBC’s Sunday Politics programme following the SDLP’s weekend conference, Mr Eastwood said his party are fighting in the upcoming Stormont poll in May “determined to be in government”, but acknowledged any decision would be based on a negotiation following the election in which the SDLP will have “very strong asks”.Under the rules of the Assembly which changed following the Stormont House agreement, parties can enter oppositionthey choose not to participate in the power sharing Executive institutions.In , Mr Eastwood took his party into official opposition at Stormont alongside the Ulster Unionist Party, with the leader claiming any decision after May  will be based on “trying to protect people in the middle of this cost-of-living crisis”.“We want to be in government, we are running to be in government,” Mr Eastwood said.“The SDLP are determined to be in government. We will go into a negotiation about what that government will actually do. I can give you a cast iron guarantee we will go into negotiations.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Read MoreSam McBride:OpinionFear and loathing hasten DUP’s decline“Of course, that option is on the table [opposition] the point is we don’t want to take that option, we want to be in government.”Challenged about recent polling figures during the interview, with both LucidTalk and a recent Irish News University of Liverpool poll putting the party on just %, Mr Eastwood hit back and said he was concerned only about “the last poll that matters”, with the party gaining south Belfast and Foyle in the  General Election.“We got huge mandates from the people. The world changes very quickly, Brexit has happened. It was six or seven years ago,” the leader explained.“I am not worried about polls. I think any objective analysis shows the SDLP has stabilised under my leadership and will grow again at this election.“I don’t frankly care what a poll says, I only care what an election says.”Mr Eastwood also said the cost-of-living crisis is the “most important issue” in the upcoming election, dismissing the idea the campaign will focus on the implications of the Northern Ireland Protocol.“When I speak to people and we have been knocking doors for months... people are telling me is they are absolutely petried about the rising cost of fuel and food, that they can#t even heat their homes. These are people out working every single day,” he added.“After that is the health service. A quarter of our population are languishing on a hospital waiting list.“I think they are the kind of issues people are most concerned about. People are telling us, and they are telling every pollster, the protocol is nowhere near their top issue.”Mr Eastwood also said discussion over the position of First Minister was part of a “phony sectarian row”, amid both main unionist parties previously unwilling to confirm whether they would support a Sinn Fein First Ministerthe republican party was to become the biggest at Stormont.“See this phony sectarian row about who is going to be top dog, it makes absolutely no dference,” the SDLP said.“If Sinn Fein win this election and the DUP come out second, we will have Sinn Fein and DUP joint First Ministers, just like the joint First Ministers have been for the past  years.”Related topicsSDLPColum EastwoodNorthern Ireland AssemblyMore On SDLP PremiumGail WalkerOpinionIf Stormont Faulkner and other Cabinet ministers address a mass rally of Vanguard supporters from the balcony of StormontMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailAt .pm, on March , , Northern Ireland’s House of Commons adjourned. It was never to meet again. Two days later the NI Temporary Provisions Act became law, introducing direct rule, ending  years of unionist government, bringing devolution to a stop and shutting down NI’s Parliament. It was the biggest crisis for unionism since the  Home Rule Bill.At lunchtime on March , Brian Faulkner, destined to be NI’s last Prime Minister, led his Cabinet onto the balcony to address the enormous crowdwhich had gathered in the grounds. He had only a loudspeaker.“People of Ulster, I am speaking to you still as Prime Minister of Northern Ireland. I want to say, not just on my own behalf, but on behalf of every one of my colleagues in the Government and the Parliamentary Party here at Stormont, that we understand absolutely the feelings which have persuaded you to come out to Parliament Buildings today… we share the resentment that you feel. We have tremendous power.“Our power is the power of our numbers our power is the justice of our cause our power is the responsibility of our conduct. Let us never play the game of the murderers of the IRA. Let us show the world that, so far as we are concerned, violence and intimidation are out. British we are and British we remain!”The previous day Faulkner had addressed an emergency meeting of the Ulster Unionist Council, informing it that his government had lost confidence in Edward Heath’s administration.By his own admission it was an angry meeting seething at what was regarded as a betrayal and surrender to unionism’s enemies. But he also warned them to shun violent responses and rely, instead, on the ‘Unionist veto’ which lay in the strength of their numbers.Exactly  years later, on Monday March , the present Assembly will be dissolved in preparation for an election on May . There are many within the unionist community who believe that, like its predecessor on March , , this institution will not meet again.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Political unionism is again seething with anger, believing that another Conservative government has betrayed it and rolled over to the demands of those who want Northern Ireland removed from the United Kingdom. Indeed, they would argue that the process of removal has been advanced by a protocol which traps Northern Ireland in some sort of constitutional halfway house between Great Britain, the Republic of Ireland and the European Union.When Brian Faulkner spoke of unionism relying on the strength of its numbers it was at a time when the combined pro-Union vote hovered around two-thirds of the overall vote.At the election for the first post-NI Parliament Assembly, in June , the pro-Union votewas %. In the  Assembly election that votehad reduced to .%.That election also saw unionism reduced to a minority within an NI Parliament and Assembly: and there is now a possibility, come May , that unionism won’t even have the numbers to qualy for the position of First Minister.And yet unionism remains as ided now as it was back in . The narrowing of the demographic gap between unionism and nationalism, along with an ongoing reluctance by successive British governments to be seen to be what might be described as pro-active on behalf of unionism, hasn’t pushed it in the direction of prioritising a coherent, collective, long-term strategy for survival.Even the thundering hammer-blows rained down on the DUP by Boris Johnson continue to be greeted with fairly mild responses from the party leadership.Speaking on Monday evening Jeffrey Donaldson acknowledged the problem: “It’s not a question of throwing the DUP under the bus. The Prime Minister threw Northern Ireland under the bus and the harm that this protocol has done to Northern Ireland is, I think, something the Prime Minister now recognises. But we need him to do something about it.”The problem, of course, is that Donaldson has been saying this since September last yearand Johnson has done nothing. He’ll continue to do nothing until May : and, in all likelihood, will do nothing after that, either.In March  Brian Faulkner and the UUP decided to risk the collapse of the NI Parliament rather than allow control of security to pass from the NI government to Westminster.A few days before Stormont was prorogued Faulkner had written to Edward Heath: ‘We wish to point out with a sense of the heavy responsibility involved that the imposition of this proposal, involving as it will the resignation of the Government of Northern Ireland as a whole, may have the gravest consequences, the full extent of which cannot now be foreseen.’We now know the primary consequence of the resignation and subsequent prorogation: the end of majority rule, the introduction of mandatory power-sharingand the sapping of unionist confidence that their future position within the United Kingdom was, to all intents and purposes, secure.What Faulkner did — although I fully understand why he had to do it — was hand over the political negotiating process to a British government which was determined to build an entirely dferent relationship with its Irish counterpart.In his biography, Memoirs of a Statesman , Faulkner hinted at regrets: “... when unionists of vision tried to stimulate new thinking and broaden the appeal of unionism in the s s I did not come out and support them. I did not think they were achieving anything useful...but we should have spent more time watering the roots of tolerance.“We did not take the initiative in reforming our society until events forced change on us. By  we were reacting to events rather than controlling them and one was always conscious of running very fast merely to make up lost ground.’Since then, a number of other unionist loyalist leaders have voiced fairly similar regrets. Sometimes about their own personal lack of foresight and sometimes about opportunities which unionism may have missed over the decades.Yet as Faulkner noted, there was always a sense that unionism was a few steps behind the thinking of others when it came to mapping out Northern Ireland’s post- future. Or, as former UUP leader Reg Empey put it, “every time unionism walks from the table it inevitably and iniably s to another table with a weaker hand”.In the early s a Minister of State based in the NIO told me: “The problem with unionism — and it’s a particular problem for those outside Northern Ireland who try to understand it — is that there are far too many ieties. They spend as much time complaining about their unionist rivals as they do complaining about their more specic political and constitutional opponents.”From until the collapse of Stormont in  the isions could mostly be controlled by the mantra — ‘United we stand. Divided we fall.’ But once the fall came there was nothing to hold unionism together and it splintered and continues to splinter.Faulkner and power-sharing were destroyed by the United Ulster Unionist Council in . Shortly afterwards the ious members of the UUUC — who couldn’t come up with an agreed alternative to the Sunningdale deal — turned on themselves.The UUP descended into civil war between -. The loyalist paramilitary groups, essential to the ‘selling’ of the Good Friday Agreement, have now withdrawn support for it. The DUP has had a horrible  months and is still beset with internal dficulties.A growing element of younger loyalism is pushing its anti-protocol campaigning towards prioritising the final collapse of the GFA institutions. And Jeffrey Donaldson and Jim Allisterhave laid down pre-election preconditions on both the protocol and the eventuality of a Sinn Fein First Minister.Change a few names and organisations and we could be talking about that period from March  to May  — when unionism and loyalism were struggling to find a route map from the crisis forced on them by widespread political societal instability and British governments which were determined to impose change upon them.But here’s the reality:the strategies and policies adopted by unionists didn’t work back then, why does anyone think terribly similar strategies and policies would work today: particularly when the constitutional crisis is worse now than then and the shadow of a border poll is hanging over every aspect of the coming election.A British state paper released in  had this assessment of the  Assembly election: ‘Mr Faulkner’s position is undoubtedly dficult. He will have less than half of the Protestant vote behind him, as Dr Paisley and others will no doubt vocerously remind him,and when he makes an effort to work the new system.“It was always to be anticipated that the Protestant vote would be fragmented… but the outcome has left the potential accepters weaker and the ‘wreckers’ stronger than expected.’Something very similar happened to David Trimble in , allowing his internal and external opponents to destroy him. Might the same thing be about to happen to Jeffrey Donaldson  Between  and  the DUP vote represented a majority of unionist votes cast — but even then, the party had to temper a lot of decisions and steer away from potential compromises and concessions. If the DUP doesn’t represent the majority of unionist votes cast and seats won in the Assembly on May  it will make it very dficult for Donaldson to reboot the executive.We seem to be on ‘the more things change, the more they stay the same’ territory for unionism. Again. But there is one dference. I was in that crowd in the grounds of Stormont on March , , a few months short of my th birthday.I recognised the scale of the shock: but I also recognised something , a new opportunity for unionism to do things dferently. My big fear today — and I’m very pessimistic, by the way, about a rebooted Assembly— is that unionism may have left it too late to do things dferently.Related topicsIRAAlliance PartyBoris JohnsonSir
