title: ‘Doughnuts’ and speeding issues on Newcastle road
story: INCREASING concern about the behaviour of motorists on the Castlewellan Road outside Newcastle has prompted calls for a speeding assessment to be carried out in the area.South Down MLA Colin McGrath and Mournes councillor Laura Devlin have been contacted by a number of residents angry about the actions of drivers performing so-called lsquodoughnutsrsquo at the Maghera Road junction with the busy main road.The area is known locally as the lsquoCup and Saucerrsquo and the politicians calling on drivers to show more consideration.Mr McGrath said the Castlewellan Road was ldquoan incredibly busy route and claimed a number of motorists drove in excess of the mph speed limit.ldquoWe must be sensitive to the needs of residents who see at first and what is happening along the road, he said.ldquoWhile speed is an issue which must be considered, residents have had to endure night time activity including drivers pulling doughnuts in their cars at this junction. This is simply not fair on local families.Mr McGrath said a pattern was emerging whereby motorists in Newcastle sped along the Shimna Road from Donard Park and made their way up the Castlewellan Road.He urged police to get to grips with the issue to ensure people who live locally are no longer subjected to such behaviour.Cllr Devlin said the ldquoselfish actions of some drivers were not fair on residents, insisting that she and Mr McGrath will support those affected by the issue any way they can.ldquoWe shall be requesting a speed assessment of the area and asking police to consider monitoring any adverse behaviour, she confirmed.ldquoWe would appeal to local familiesthey do witness any reckless behaviour on the roads that could endanger lives to report it to police so they can gather all the necessary data..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch Camera Club competition in memory of Charlie
story: BALLYNAHINCH Camera Club members welcomed Vitorrio Silvestri, from CPA Camera Club, last Thursday night to judge the entries which had been submitted for the annual Charlie Rutledge Memorial competition.Charlie was a much loved and respected founding member of Ballynahinch Camera Club and his great passion was mono photography.After Charlie passed away in  it was decided to hold a competition each year in his memory and what other genre of photographs could such a competition attract but black and white Vitorrio gave a critique on each image and, in some cases, demonstrated how they could be improved. He chose images from the following club members as the prize winners:st Terry Hanna, nd Muriel Darling, rd Frances Price highly commended and commended, John McCullough.At the end of the meeting, members were given a challenge for the next meeting. The challenge is to produce self-portraits using as much imagination and as many dferent techniques as possible. One such technique could be multiplicity mdash watch this space.New members are always welcome andanyone with an interest in photography would like more details of joining the club they should visit the club website: www.ballynahinchcameraclub..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch road bypass deay
story: FEARS are growing that the start of construction work on Ballynahinchrsquos eagerly-awaited new bypass faces a further delay.It was hoped that work on the multi-million pound scheme linking the Belfast and Newcastle roads would have started soon after a so-called lsquodirection orderrsquo was signed last year by Stormont Infrastructure Minister Nicola Mallon.It has emerged that just a handful of weeks before the Assembly is dissolved ahead of the May  election that she will not be signing a so-called commencement order paving the way for work on the scheme to start.However, Mrs Mallon has revealed that her departmentrsquos funding bid for the next three years included money to deliver the Ballynahinch scheme, explaining that the absence of an Executive means there is no agreed budget resulting in delivery timescales remaining uncertain.The bypass is included in a list of strategic and flagship road improvement schemes alongside Newryrsquos proposed southern relief road, bypasses in Enniskillen and Cookstown and junction improvements along the A.The latest delay in starting construction work has been criticised by South Down MP Chris Hazzard and veteran Ballynahinch bypass campaigner Francie Casement.Mr Hazzard has described the failure to commence the bypass during the current Assembly term as a ldquokick in the teeth for local residents and commuters across the constituency.He said that for more than two years, the people of Ballynahinch and wider South Down area had been waiting for a ldquopositive, proactive statement of intent from the current roads minister regarding the bypass.ldquoUnfortunately, we have been left waiting and the scheme remains on the shelf, the MP declared.ldquoAt just poundm, the project costs for the Ballynahinch scheme are relatively minor for a government department that boasts a huge capital budget of more than poundm per year. The Ballynahinch scheme represents excellent value for money and should have been prioritised during the past two years.Mr Hazzard said more than poundbn of capital resources has been spent by the roads minister and her department during the letime of the current Assembly.ldquoIt is hugely disappointing that a small, yet strategically important scheme, such as the Ballynahinch bypass has been left on the shelf. In light of the economic impact of Covid- and the ongoing Brexit uncertainty, the commencement of this scheme would have been a welcome step towards improving both our local economy and the wellbeing of the local community, said the MP.Mr Hazzard added: ldquoWe can only hope now that when the Executive is restored after Mayrsquos election, that the local community can have a minister in place who recognises the value of the Ballynahinch bypass and finally begins construction.Mr Casement said the bypass could help kick-start the economic regeneration of the town and provide the wider South Down tourism economy with a signicant boost. He said it was vital a start date for construction work is confirmed as soon as possible.A key member of Ballynahinchrsquos Regeneration Committee for many years alongside the late Vincent Fullam, Mr Casement has never given up the battle to secure a bypass, which was first mooted in the late s.ldquoThe bypass is included in a list of strategic projects and is effectively ready to proceed. There should be no more delays. The scheme should have been delivered years ago, he declared.ldquoWhile the primary focus of the bypass is on easing traffic congestion, there are many other benefits, including reduced town centre pollution.Mr Casement added: ldquoThe new road scheme will also dissuade drivers from using built-up housing areas and rural roads as unofficial bypasses and, most importantly, help kick-start the economic regeneration of Ballynahinch town centre. We need to see work starting on the scheme now.A Department for Infrastructure spokesman said it was committed to delivering the bypass as part of a plan to aid economic recovery and community transformation, while addressing regional imbalance.He said that ldquofar from being left on the shelf, the scheme was being actively progressed much further by Ms Mallon than any other minister, with development work now substantively complete and statutory approvals finalised in July last year.ldquoThe next stage would involve commencing the procurement of a contractor but progression to procurement and construction is dependent upon the level of funding made available to the Department in future budgets, he explained.ldquoThe Departmentrsquos bid for the - budget included funds to deliver this scheme, however, the absence of an Executive means there is no agreed budget which means that delivery timescales remain uncertain.The spokesman added: ldquoThis is a priority for our Minister who remains frustrated that once again the absence of an Executive is negatively affecting both the people of Northern Ireland and our infrastructure..prettyPhoto

title: Carryduff landowner helps the environment with trees
story: CARRYDUFF landowner Rosanna Ballentine and her son Iain have received  trees to plant on their farm to help them enhance bioersity and create a habitat for wildle.The trees have been supplied from a partnership between Trees on the Land ndash a charity and not-for-profit project from the Green Economy Foundation ndash and SuperValu and Centra, part of the Musgrave Group.The project is part of a sustainability initiative from the retail brands which recently announced they will plant , trees across Northern Ireland over ten years.Mrs Ballentine welcomed the initiative and the assistance of SuperValu and Centra staff, along with central colleagues from Musgrave NI, who pulled on their wellies and visited the farm to help plant a mix of hawthorn, oak, birch, rowan and hazel trees.She said: ldquoWe are planting a new native hedgerow and a line of trees along the edge of an existing woodland to ide it from an adjoining agricultural grassland. Thanks to Trees on the Land, SuperValu and Centra, we can not only improve bioersity and create habitat for wildle but also soak up carbon.ldquoWe were delighted to welcome volunteers from our two local stores, as well as some of Musgraversquos central colleagues, to help with the tree planting.Already this year the retailers have sponsored , native trees, including  at the Carryduff farm. Centra Carryduff owner David Martin explained: ldquoAt Centra, we care about sustainability and wersquore very pleased to be involved with this project. It was great to be able to help with the planting and hear from Rosanna and Ian about the benefits that these trees will bring.SuperValu store manager Jim Brennan added: ldquoThis is a very worthwhile initiative and will create many long-term positive benefits for the area. We were delighted to help out and this project is just one that demonstrates our commitment to making a positive impact in the communities we serve..prettyPhoto

title: Castlewellan trio in the ‘Big Apple’
story: THREE young Gaelic footballers from Castlewellan had an important role to play in last weekrsquos St Patrickrsquos Day parade in New York.Former Down goalkeeper Michael Cunningham and his team-mates, Paddy Boyle and Aidan Doherty, were given the honour of leading the Co Down contingent in the historic event which was watched by millions across the world on NBC television.All three played senior football for Castlewellan and are still highly regarded in their native Club.Michael was even given a name check by the impressively well informed commentator, who said he was looking forward to playing in goal for New York in the forthcoming game against Sligo in the Connaught championship.The opportunity to lead the Down contingent was described by Michael as ldquoan unbelievable honour and one which he would never forget.ldquoWe all feel very honoured and privileged to have been chosen.To experience the incredible atmosphere, the crowds, the bands, the colour and the cheers was just out of this world, he said.The first New York St Patrickrsquos Day parade was held in  mdash  years before the first similar event in Dublin took place in  mdash and has long been widely accepted to be among the biggest in the world..prettyPhoto

title: Celtic Bhoys lift the   Bobby Dalzell Cup
story: CELTIC Bhoys were crowned Bobby Dalzell Cup champions after defeating local rivals Ardglass in the deciding penalty shoot-out at Meadowvale last Thursday.A goal on the stroke of half-time from Ardglass midfielder Stephen Deegan was cancelled out on  minutes by the close range effort of Celtic striker Jordan McCoubrey.The teams refused to be split in extra-time and following the shoot-out mdash which went well into the sudden death stages mdash Blaine Connolly converted the all-important spot kick to gt his Hoopsrsquo side the victory.A large crowd turned out in Drumaness for the St Patrickrsquos Day showpiece between the current first and second-placed sides in the Newcastle Leaguersquos Premier Division.Adding to the pressure of the occasion was the alternating weather conditions, with the teams contesting the final in periods of sunshine as well as wind and rain.Nevertheless, Celtic kicked off the affair with the blustery conditions heavily in favour of their opponents.It didnrsquot take long for the tone of the match to be set as Ardglass defender Caolain OrsquoShea launched a very physical tackle on Hoops striker Jay Gibney.Ardglass enjoyed early momentum with experienced defender Neil Teggart seeing his wind-assisted free kick from his own half trouble Celtic custodian Nathan Curran less than ten minutes in.Celtic remained calm and soon strung their passes together through clever one touch football with eventual man of the match winner Conor Doherty in the thick of these sequences.However, Ardglass remained a threat and came close when Teggart clipped a cross into the danger area, although striker Michael Magee glanced his header wide.Stand-in Celtic captain Shaun Megahey attempted to play a through ball to team-mate Gibney, but on this occasion the Ardglass defence timed the offside trap perfectly.Celtic did come close when Barry Treacyrsquos corner kick was fumbled by Ardglass lsquokeeper, Mark Armstrong, although Hoops defender Paul Brady couldnrsquot dispatch the ball quickly enough before the danger was cleared.OrsquoShea continued his earlier eagerness and picked up a yellow card for a mistimed tackle before his team-mate, Magee, was unfairly clattered at the other end of the pitch, although Teggartrsquos effort flew past the wrong side of the post.Teggart continued to be a problem from set pieces as his free-kick delivery whisked past the head of striker Magee and out of bounds.Moments later, Mageersquos misfortune continued when he was shown a yellow card for expressing his disagreement with referee, Barry Mullan.After initially allowing the match to flow freely, referee Mullan clamped down on his decisions with less than ten minutes to the end of the opening half.Celtic defender Gary Carberry was the latest to enter the book for a late challenge on Ardglass marksman Magee.Despite this hiccup, Celticrsquos Carberry kept himself in contention for the man of the match accolade after he proved pivotal in stopping potential goalscoring chances from the Ardglass opposition on numerous occasions.As the half-time whistle approached, Celtic arms were raised as they appealed for the red card to be shown to Ardglassrsquos OrsquoShea, who may have considered himself lucky to escape an early bath after he was second to the ball.Ardglass launched another attack and it looked asMagee would have a free route to goal. However, Celtic veteran Brady recovered valiantly to prove he still has plenty of miles left in his tank.With the last attack of the half, Ardglass were awarded a corner and they took full advantage of their opportunity. Midfielder, Stephen Deegan, climbed high above the rest to head his effort beyond the outstretched hand of Celtic lsquokeeper Curran to open the scoring.As the second half kicked off it was evident that both sides would refrain from going for broke. A lot of the following ten minutes contained attacks, although both sides lacked a killer instinct and the match was heavily contested in the middle of the pitch.This is where Conor Doherty earned his post-match award for his performance, as he often won the midfield battle.Goal-scorer Deegan picked up a yellow as the weather took yet another turn for the worse.Celtic joint-managers Jason Galbraith and Matthew McKenna made the first of their substitutions as the clock struck the hour mark with Sean McMahon entering the fray in place of Conaill Kerr.Ardglass opted to put  men behind the ball in order to frustrate the opposition and waited patiently for their opportunity to counter-attack.Ardglass made changes of their own in the form of Jordan Finnegan before Celtic made a second substitute with the talented Sean Ferris making his way onto the pitch.Ferris made an immediate impact, adding another string to Celticrsquos bow by spreading inviting passes into his forward line.With just  minutes left of the , these Celtic substitutions came to fruition after the ball found its way to McMahon, who lofted an inviting ball into the Ardglass box which was steered home by the boot of striker McCoubrey.Celtic continued to mix things up as Corey McCartan made his way onto the pitch and gave a good account of himself with his tireless work rate.Despite this period of succession for the Hoops, the remaining minutes of the  played out finely balanced.Ardglass never let their headsand should be commended for their effort as they cancelled out any further attack whilst continuously seeking the crucial next goal.As tempers flared, the final whistle sounded and both teams prepared for extra-time.The highlights of the first half of extra-time came in the form of Celticrsquos Treacy picking up a yellow card before team-mate Ferris crashed his left-footed effort off the crossbar.During the next interval, both of Ardglassrsquo Magee and Celticrsquos Ferris threatened but they couldnrsquot do enough to get the ball over the line and it would be penalties that would decide the final outcome.Amongst the numerous penalties which took place, both Celtic and Ardglass players were ordered to retake their spot kicks.Firstly, Celtic striker McCoubrey saw his effort denied by Armstrong before referee Mullan blew his whistle after adjudging the Ardglass custodian to be off his line as the penalty was taken.McCoubrey fired in the retake and it wouldnrsquot be long before Ardglass substitute Finnegan would go through a similar course of events after he missed his initial penalty but converted at the second time of asking.Eventually, as the penalties progressed well into sudden death, Celticrsquos Blaine Connolly remained calm and converted the deciding spot kick to send the Hoopsrsquo support into delirium as his side were crowned champions.Following the conclusion, man of the match Conor Doherty gave his thoughts on his sidersquos victory.ldquoI thought we were the better team in the first half but then they snuck a goal before half-time, he said.ldquoBut, even with the wind we started to press on, it was a long  minutes.ldquoIt was a hard hitting game but Irsquom just glad we got on the winning side of it.He added: ldquoAll the penalties were top class, it was a really good shootout.Celtic Bhoys: N Curran, S Megahey , B Connolly, P Brady, G Carberry, C Doherty, B Treacy, P Casey, J Gibney, J McCoubrey, C Kerr.Subs: S McMahon, S Ferris, C McCartan, R Fitzpatrick, R Quinn.Yellow cards: G Carberry, B TreacyArdglass: M Armstrong, M Crangle, L McEvoy, N Teggart, C OrsquoShea, M Rooney , S Deegan, S-P Halpin, M Magee, C Kearney, C OrsquoConnorSubs: S Dorrian, J Finnegan, J Deegans, A OrsquoShea, B CrangleYellow cards: C OrsquoShea, M Magee, S DeeganReferee: Barry Mullan.prettyPhoto

title: Council official to leave for new post
story: ONE of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos most senior officials is to leave the organisation.Ms Dorinnia Carville mdash the local authorityrsquos current deputy chief executive mdash has been nominated as the new Comptroller and Auditor General for Northern Ireland.Her appointment has been confirmed by Assembly speaker Alex Maskey who is also chairman of the Assembly Commission.He confirmed that following the conclusion of the recruitment process, the Assembly Commission identied Ms Carville for nomination to the important role, which is instrumental in ensuring that public funds are spent wisely.ldquoIt is vital that all public bodies are held to the highest standards, said Mr Maskey.ldquoWhere public bodies, including Northern Ireland Departments, have not adhered to best practice, it is theof the Comptroller and Auditor General to make recommendations so that best practice is followed and lessons are learnt.Mr Maskey said Ms Carville brings a wealth of experience and expertise to the role of Comptroller and Auditor General for Northern Ireland, with a career that is rich in public sector audit experience.He added: ldquoI have no doubt that Ms Carville will serve the public sector professionally and diligently.The Assembly Commission tabled a motion for debate at a sitting yesterday when MLAs were given the opportunity to agree Ms Carvillersquos formal nomination.Ms Carville graduated from Belfastrsquos Queenrsquos University with a degree in Law, with Politics.She is a chartered accountant who trained and worked in leading private sector accountancy firms in London and Belfast, before moving into public sector audit, joining the Northern Ireland Audit Officeand gaining experience auditing a wide range of public bodies in Northern Ireland.Over the course of  years, Ms Carville held a number of positions in the NIAO including financial audit director and director of corporate services.In this position, she was the technical director providing technical audit advice to the Comptroller and Auditor General and the Local Government Auditor and represented the NIAO on the Public Audit Forum with colleagues from the audit offices in England, Wales and Scotland.Following the review of public administration, Ms Carville moved into local government as Director of Corporate Services at Newry Mourne and Down Council in .She is the local authorityrsquos senior financial officer and is also responsible for a wide range of corporate services including audit, human resources, legal and compliance, communications and marketing and capital projects.She is responsible for the organisationrsquos Audit and Strategy, Policy and Resources committees. Since February, she has been acting chief executive, deputising for Mrs Marie Ward.Ms Carville also holds a number of voluntary roles in the public sector as well as the voluntary and community sector, including as a Board Trustee for Belfast and Lisburn Womenrsquos Aid..prettyPhoto

title: Crossgar girl going for chop
story: GENEROUS Crossgar girl Lily Magee is chopping off her long locks for a very good cause.The  year-old is raising money for the Little Princess Trust, a charity which provides a real hair wig to any child who has lost theirs due to cancer.A pupil at St Brigidrsquos Primary School in Downpatrick, Lily has already raised more than pound on her fundraising page.Her mother, Laura, explained that her daughter has been wanting to have her hair cut for some time.ldquoHer hair is down past her hip and she plans to get cm of it cut, leaving her with shoulder- hair, said Mrs Magee.ldquoShe hasnrsquot had her hair cut since the first lockdown. Itrsquos got so long that itrsquos a big unmanageable and she canrsquot put in her own hair bobble.ldquoLily has been wanting to get it cut for a while now. We saw that other local girls had their hair cut for The Little Princess Trust and we decided to wait until we could raise money as well as getting her hair cut at the same time.Lily, older sister to brothers Louis and Leo, will be getting the big chop at Precious Hair Design in Downpatrick on April .She added: ldquoThis is a big deal for me as I love having long hair. Any donation, however small is greatly appreciated. Thank you in advance for your contribution. I hope I can help to make someone happy in my own small way.To support Lily and The Little Princess Trust please visit Lilyrsquos Locks Get The Chop! on www.gofundme..prettyPhoto

title: Down relegated from Division 2 following loss to struggling Cork side
story: DOWN senior footballersrsquo torrid campaign has ended in relegation following the Mourne sidersquos loss to Cork on Sunday.James McCartan has yet to register a league win since recapturing his managerial role ndash with five losses and one draw ndash and now his attention turns to saving Down from further despair.The relegation means the Mourne men will hope to rebuild and reset next year in Division , although the immediate worry now is the possibility of playing second-tier championship football. To avoid this, Down must manufacture a route to an Ulster final.It was a scrap for survival at Paacuteirc Uiacute Chaoimh as both the hosts and visitors looked to register their first victory to escape the immediate .Unfortunately for Down, Cork corner-forward Steven Sherlock was on top form and constantly proved a threat in front of goal.The St Finbarrrsquos footballer, who recently reached the All-Ireland club semi-finals, ended the match with a personal tally of -, a mere five points off Downrsquos overall scoring.It was anyonersquos game during the opening quarter with both sides exchanging points but neither increasing their lead past the minimum.Down managed the windy conditions well but were dealt an early blow when Niall McParland exited the pitch due to injury with just  minutes played and moments later it would go from bad to worse.A Cork goal from Sherlock gave his side breathing space and by half-time, it was this score which proved the dference as Down trailed - to -.Darren OrsquoHagan and Anthony Doherty kicked over for Down in the opening minutes of the second half after Cork had added more points to their tally.Down were given renewed le when Tiernan Rushe struck the back of the net, reducing the deficit to a single score.However, the next three scores went in the way of Cork, two of which left the boot of the impressive Sherlock.To the Mourne sidersquos credit, they replied with a trio of unanswered points but they were still hoping to close the gap and the clock was quickly ticking down.Despite their efforts, Down just couldnrsquot do enough to pull ahead after the interval and the contest ended with the Mourne side trailing by four.This timely win for Cork sets them up fora relegation play-off with Offaly whilst Down play out their remaining Division  fixture against Clare at Paacuteirc Esler on Sunday.This weekendrsquos clash means little as the Mourne outfitrsquos fate has been sealed, although a win on home soil may gt the players with a much needed confidence boost ahead of their Ulster campaign.Cork: M Martin K OrsquoDonovan, K Flahive, K Histon J Cooper, R Maguire, M TaylorI Maguire, C OrsquoCallaghanD Dineen , E McSweeney, J OrsquoRourkeS Sherlock , B Hurley, C OrsquoMahony .Subs: T Walsh for HistonB Murphy for SherlockM Croninfor HurleyC Kiely for McSweeneyJ Grimes for OrsquoRourke .Down: R Burns P Fegan, F McElroy, G Collins D OrsquoHagan , C Poland, C DohertyA Doherty, N McParland A Morgan, L Kerr, R McEvoyA Gilmore , P Havern , C Quinn .Subs: K McKernan for McParlandT Rushefor QuinnG McMahon for BurnsR OrsquoHigginsfor Morgan .Referee: B Grfin ..prettyPhoto

title: Down U
story: DOWN U- girls came into their third competitive match weekend looking to bounce back from two defeats in match day two.Playing at home in Liatroim gave the local girls and management a great incentive to get back to winning ways.The opening game of the weekend against Tyrone played out in dry but windy conditions. Down looked to take advantage of playing with this wind in the first half and were getting good scores on the board.However, Tyrone stayed in the game with two goals to leave the half time score - to - in favour of Down.Tightening up the midfield at half-time and with Down now playing against the wind, the Mourne side took the game to Tyrone. The match was very open and for every half chance that went in for Down, Tyrone missed theirs.In the end, Down ran out deserved easy winners. Final score: Down - Tyrone -.Scorers for Down were Grace McMullan , Anna McArdle , Isa McCarron , Clodagh Simpson , Orla Owensand Annie McEvoy .Good performances all-round the pitch. Best performers for Down were Annie McEvoy, Holly Donnelly, Anna McArdle, Eloise Austin, Isa McCarron, Grace McMullan and captain Orla Owens but it was Zara Kelly who took the player of the match award.In the next contest against Monaghan, Down played against the wind in the first half. Making  changes to the starting teams from the Tyrone match meant all  girls in the  got starting a game.The match was very tight from the off and was a very low scoring affair with very little clearcut goal-scoring opportunities.In a tight first half, Down were happy to come in at the interval with a score from Cliodhna McGrath, who notched a great point from open play.In the second half, the Mourne side introduced a few fresh legs again as they aimed to take advantage of the wind.Although Down initially outscored their Monaghan counterparts - to -, the visitors stayed in the match and continuously looked for goals.Some frantic defending and some very solid goalkeeping kept Monaghan out and in the end the local girls came through with a - to - win.The tightest of wins but well deserved on the day. Scorers for Down were Holly Donnelly , Lucia Keane , Grace Kellyand Cliodhna McGrath .Again a solid effort from all the girls in this match, but the best performers were Zara Greenan in nets, Ellen Farrell, Helen McGeough, Daire OrsquoShea, Hannah Cassin, Evie McHugh, Lucia Keane and captain Aoe Wolfe.However, it was Grace Kelly who took the player of the match award. Two good wins, six more points on the board but most importantly, another couple of solid performances from the squad..prettyPhoto

title: East Down enjoy St Patrick’s Day
story: WITH St Patrickrsquos Day offering a midweek holiday for many, what better way to spend it than running in a race A few East Down AC members travelled to Belfast to take part in the Craic K which is described as an urban road race taking in the city sights.It was an early start at am and while it was nippy at first, it soon warmed up.The route wasnrsquot too hilly apart from the last couple of kilometres leading into the finish at Ormeau Park and there was good support from the crowd so it was an enjoyable event.Deirdre Weatherall had a storming run in . which placed her rd out of . Clare Carson came in in ., breaking  minutes with ease.Donal Smith, who is in the midst of running every day for  days in the lead up to his th birthday, was happy to have company to tick a day off and was pleased with his . as part of his comeback venture.Kevin Kelly was out as a pacer and encourager and finished comfortably and smiling. All agreed that it was a good day out.On Saturday Sam Anderson, as part of her build up to Belfast Marathon, took on the Larne Ten Miles.The coast was spectacular in the sunshine and she felt that the views helped the time to pass while running.She clocked ., which she was happy with, but more importantly felt comfortable with the distance which will boost her confidence no end.The Fallows Race ndash the second round of the NI Mountain Running AssociationChampionships ndash took place the same day as Larne.Starting in Kilbroney Forest Park in Rostrevor, the route then took the runners out on to Slieve Martin with m of climbing in the km distance.The first early climb took about  minutes for the front pack so it was tough from the get go.Timothy Johnston of Mourne Runners took the overall win in ... East Down AC was well represented by Aaron McGrady.Having come third in Jimmyrsquos Ten the week previous, he might have been excused for taking the weekend off but he couldnrsquot resist the mountains.It was a perfect day, dry and bright with blue skies so the scenery was at its best.He kept up with the lead bunch for well into an hour of racing but the second big climb took its toll and he was left hanging on for the finish.At one stage he was third behind Jonathan Scott but a pass by Adam Cunninghamput him into fourth.Aaron finished in .., approximately two minutes behind the leader which is a commendable performance.Despite missing podium, he thoroughly enjoyed his race and is looking forward to the next outing.With Jimmyrsquos Ten done and dusted, East Down Athletics Club is getting back to business as usual.The annual membership night takes place next Monday in the clubrooms.Both ing and new adult members are welcome .-.pm to sign up for the year ahead.If you are considering joining for the first time and want to find out more, please contact membership@eastdownac.The junior section is at capacity so unfortunately only current athletes are invited to renew at this time. Sign on from .-.pm.There are lots of races looming from K to marathon and beyond so have a look at the fixture list at https:athleticsni.org Fixtures to set yourself a spring goal and then get yourself out the door and get running.It is the best time of the year to enjoy the benefits of sport..prettyPhoto

title: Farmers opposed to Poots%2C says MP
story: AN overwhelming majority of farmers who responded to future farming proposals outlined by Stormont Agriculture Minister Edwin Poots have rejected the new policy direction, according to South Down MP Chris Hazzard.He said that in recent days, it has been revealed that over % of farmersrsquo responses were critical of the ministerrsquos views for the future of farming.The MP said that, having talked to many local farmers across the constituency over recent months, he was ldquonot at all surprised by the news.ldquoIt was clear that the DUP agriculture ministerrsquos plans undermine our small family farms, ignore our sheep farmers and penalise those who farm our hills and mountains, suggested Mr Hazzard.ldquoUnder these controversial proposals, , small farms below  hectares will be denied funding, including many of our local farms here in South Down. This is totally unfair and, given the huge backlash, the ministerrsquos plans must now be scrapped.Also this week, Mr Hazzardrsquos Sinn Fein colleague, Cathy Mason, who is one of the partyrsquos South Down Assembly election candidates, has urged Mr Poots to intervene to help farmers with a financial package to alleviate the rising costs of feed and fertiliser."Farmers and their families are, like everyone , being impacted with the cost of living crisis. They are facing increased costs for food, energy and fuel in tandem with specic business costs with spiralling increases to the cost of feed and fertilisers. This is having a serious impact on many farmers and their families, she said.ldquoThese implications would have a devastating impact on our farmers in South Down who have little option but to use red diesel in their tractors and other agriculture machinery used for farming and food production.ldquoThis increase in red diesel cost, in addition to the uncertainty on Brexit and plummeting farm gate prices, will place serious strain on farmers.This is a problem that looks certain to continue and will be exacerbated by the Russian invasion of Ukraine which is a main supplier of these products.Mrs Mason said Mr Poots needed to intervene and ldquoprovide support, including a financial package, to help farmers through this crisis..prettyPhoto

title: Forsythe selected for DUP in South Down
story: THE DUP has formally selected its local Assembly election candidates to contest the May election.Diane Forsythe will be the partyrsquos standard bearer in South Down, while Crossgarrsquos Harry Harvey is one of three runners in Strangford where he is joined by Michelle McIlveen and Peter Weir.Earlier this year, Mrs Forsythe was chosen ahead of sitting MLA Jim Wells to contest the South Down seat and is looking forward to the election.ldquoI am delighted to have been selected to contest the Assembly election in South Down for the DUP, she said.ldquoIt is an honour and privilege to have the opportunity to represent this area where I live.ldquoWe are a thriving, vibrant area which I want to do my best to enhance and grow. We have so many opportunities across our industries, fishing, farming, manufacturing and many more.I want to work for everyone to secure improved investment in all of these sectors to boost this area and make us a central tourist attraction for the country.Mrs Forsythe said she wanted to help everyone in the constituency ldquowhere many are struggling and need support to access services.She continued: ldquoOur healthcare, roads infrastructure and support for working families in the squeezed middle of society need improvement. I want to be their voice in Stormont to make le better, she continued.ldquoI grew up in Ballymartin and am raising my three primary school aged children here. I was educated in Kilkeel Primary School and Kilkeel High School and am a law graduate from Queenrsquos University.Mrs Forsythe is also a qualied chartered accountant and her professional career includes ten years in public sector financial audit, three years in local manufacturing industry finance and three years as a financial manager in the charity sector.She added: ldquoI am looking forward to speaking to everyone on the doorsteps in the coming weeks andanyone wants to enquirethey are registered to vote in South Down or meet me for assistance with securing a postal or proxy vote please get in touch.Mr Harvey said he is ldquohonouredrsquo to have secured his partyrsquos nomination to contest the Strangford seat alongside existing colleagues Michelle McIlveen and Peter Weir.Mr Harvey was co-opted to the Assembly in  to replace Simon Hamilton and is a former Newry, Mourne and Down councillor.ldquoI am delighted to have been chosen to contest the May election and getting out to meet people and discuss the issues of concern to them. I believe that when people work together they get things done and make le better for everyone, he added..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C  March 25%2C 1992
story: NEWCASTLE mdash A total of  new jobs which would have been created by the construction of a new factory in Newcastle have been lost because the Industrial Development Board ldquodid nothing to help, it was claimed yesterday.The United Kingdom-based toy manufacturing firm is pulling out and the factory is now likely to be established in England.A spokesman for the prospective developers confirmed yesterday they are aborting the Newcastle plan.Mr T H Martin said: ldquoI would have thought that the job of the IDB was to encourage employment and, bearing in mind we propose to create upwards of  jobs, this appears not to be the case.ldquoThe IDB seems more concerned about getting an unrealistic current price for land which, over many years, has lain idle.ldquoIt is with great regret that we no longer have the time nor the inclination to continue these negotiations. If this is the attitude adopted by the IDB then it is no wonder Northern Ireland has an extremely high unemployment rate, he added.Details of the prospective jobs boost were revealed yesterday by local Ulster Unionist councillor, Mr Gerry Douglas, who claimed the IDB has done nothing at all to assist the proposed project.DOWNPATRICK mdash The St Patrickrsquos Day celebrations in Downpatrick were a great success, according to Down Council chairman, Mr Sean Quinn.Mr Quinn said the parade was the most successful ever held in the town and he paid tribute to the organising committee and to the council officials for their hard work leading up to the event.He added that the district has been pushed to the forefront like never before, and he thanked Ulster Television for filming a week-long series of news reports from the town.ldquoWe have had a most important St Patrickrsquos Day which went down in the history of the district as one of the most successful we have ever had, said Mr Quinn.He also paid tribute to the work done by the churches and, in particular, the Church of Ireland Bishop, Dr Gordon McMullan, for his service of peace in Down Cathedral.ldquoSt Patrickrsquos Day was a wonderful coming together of the council, the community and the churches in the town, said Mr Quinn.CASTLEWELLAN mdash The Seeconnell Initiative near Castlewellan yesterday received pound.m under a major new rural development initiative.The funding was announced by the chairman of the International Fund for Ireland, Mr John McGuckian, and is aimed at helping the local initiative to regenerate what was once a thriving community.Seeconnell, close to Slieve Croob, is the first area to benefit under a new Rural Development Initiative. Mr McGuckian explained that this represents an extension to the Disadvantaged Areas Initiative which currently comprises the CERS and CRISP programmes. It will be administered in the province by the Department of Agriculture.Seeconnell will receive its funding from the International Fund which will give pound, the European Community initiative under the LEADER programme will give pound, pound, from the Department of Agriculture and the balance of pound, funded by the community.KILLYLEAGH mdash A sketch drawing of a proposed new business centre for Killyleagh has gone on display in the town.The centre is being proposed by the Killyleagh and District Development Committee as one of the key elements to help trigger the local economy.The centre would provide space for starter business units with professional support provided by the districtrsquos enterprise agency, Jobspace. The business centre would also encompass a multi-purpose meeting room.The committee, which is headed by local businessman, Mr Michael Heron, is seeking funding under the CRISP programme of the Department of Environment and the International Fund.It would act as the lsquocorersquo project to trigger other public and private sector investment in the town in areas such as upgrading footpaths, improving lighting and restoring derelict buildings.STRANGFORD mdash The Department of the Environment has been urged not to cancel a package of improvements for Strangford.The appeal was made by the chairman of Strangford Village Committee, Mr John Steenson, who said the recent decision by residents to veto plans for a new ferry jetty should not jeopardise improvements earmarked for the village.Speaking at the committeersquos annual meeting, Mr Steenson said a new, re-styled ferry terminal would be widely welcomed by residents, while a traffic scheme in the DoE car park would do much to reduce traffic congestion within the village.Mr Steenson said he was ldquogratied by the number of residents who attended the public meeting at which the improvements were discussed.ldquoThe great majority at the meeting were implacably opposed to the building of what seemed to them to be a long and unsightly jetty into the lough to act as a mooring for the two ferries, Mr Steenson remarked.ldquoAlthough there was no detailed discussion of the committeersquos suggestion that the ferry terminal be relocated outside the village, or the village by-passed by a new road, I think most people accepted, able reluctantly, that the proposal was simply not possible because of the cost, he said.KILLYLEAGH mdash Delamont Country Park, outside Killyleagh, looks set to be officially opened around Easter, it was agreed this week.Down Council is to push ahead with the opening arrangements following complaints that it has taken too long to get the prestigious project off the ground.Councillors have complained that a prime opportunity to publicise the park has been missed because it was not possible to hold an official opening when Ulster Television was filming in the district over St Patrickrsquos week.At the monthly council meeting it was also revealed that a businessman, who has opened a garden centre in Delamont, is annoyed because he was told the official opening would take place at Halloween last year.Mr John Cushnie opened his centre in July  and he claims he was given assurances by council officers that the park would officially open within four months.When the opening did not take place, Mr Cushnie went back to the councilrsquos recreation committee and only last month was told the opening ceremony would take place around St Patrickrsquos Day.Another businessman, who plans to open an exotic bird centre at Delamont, claims he has been kept waiting for firm proposals regarding the piece of land on which he needs to build the centre.ARDGLASS mdash District nursing sisters Philomena Hanna and Pauline McEvoy are continuing a tradition which dates back to the th century and Florence Nightingale.Butthe district nurse had her beginnings in Victorian Britain, she is very much a part of the late th century, having at her disposal all the skills and resources of the modern health service.Even sock there remains the fundamental commitment to the wellbeing of the community which inspired the founders more than  years ago. Based in Ardglass, Sisters Hanna and McEvoy carry on the tradition of combining the roles of nurse, friend and comforter.It was on the advice of Florence Nightingale, lsquoThe Lady With the Lamprsquo who sprang to national prominence for her pioneering work during the Crimean War, that a certain William Rathbone established the first training school for district nurses in .The aim was to educate women in all aspects of nursing care and therefore bring relief to the poor who were living in appalling conditions in the urban slums created as a consequence of the Industrial Revolution.By , there were  district nurses in the Liverpool area. As the benefits quickly became apparent, the service spread to other parts of Britain. The Queenrsquos Institute of Nursing set up its own training school and by  ndash when the National Health Service came into being ndash district nursing was available to  per cent of the population..prettyPhoto

title: Hinch whiskey now big tipple in Boston
story: ST Patricks Day revellers in Boston enjoyed locally produced Hinch Whiskey to celebrate Irelandrsquos patron saint.As Boston marked St Patrickrsquos Day for the first time since the global pandemic, Hinch Distillery near Ballynahinch was also celebrating as its brands were served for the first time in world famous bars in the city.Michael Morris, international sales director at Hinch Distillery, said: ldquoAt the centre of the action on St Patrickrsquos Day was world famous bars in Boston and we hosted a live feed on the day back to the distillery.ldquoThe Hinch International team was on hand to celebrate the brandrsquos launch in the Boston venues and help promote Hinch products at other venues in the city, the state and the national network.ldquoIt is hoped, with the brandrsquos prominence in Boston, it will be recognised as a new, serious player in what is the most important market for Irish whiskey in the world.He added: ldquoHinch Irish Whiskey has become a firm favourite locally and internationally. Itrsquos great that our distillery is open and expanding, and we can shout about the success our spirits have been making behind the scenes.St Patrickrsquos Day coincided with Hinch Distilleryrsquos recent win at the International Wine and Spirit Competition .This month the distillery also gained two prestigious Spirit Silver Awards for its Ninth Wave Gin and Ninth Wave Export Strength Gin.The accolades saw the gins receive  points and  points respectively, which is one of the highest scores that can be given to a product in the competition.Meanwhile, Hinch Irish Whiskey won the Small Company Product Category at the  Northern Ireland Food and Drink Awards, showcasing Northern Ireland food and drink companies.Hinch Distillery chairman, Dr Terry Cross OBE, said: ldquoWe have continued to develop our offering, expand our portfolio and win major deals in the shadows of what has been a very challenging economic climate..prettyPhoto

title: It’s the end of the road on Dancing for Matthew
story: IT was the last dance for Love Island star Matthew MacNabb on Sunday when he was voted off Dancing With The Stars Ireland.The  year-old Downpatrick man may not have made it to the final, but he found romance mdash something he failed to do on the top ITV dating show.He and professional dance partner Laura Nolanfinally confirmed their relationship with a kiss after they knew their time on the RTE show had come to an end.Matthewrsquos Samba mdash a notoriously dficult dance for celebrities mdashwas danced to One Dance by Justin Bieber.Scoring him  points, the judges were impressed by Matthewrsquos efforts.Brian Redmond remarked: ldquoMatthew, you know this might be a bit of a surprise. That actually wasnrsquot bad. Reverse samba rolls. You did move the hips, not perfect, bits still missing but it was very good.Loraine Barry said: ldquoWhen people hear samba they go, oh no, oh no.But I think you should both be very proud. Hips were moving. It was recognisable. Timing was there. Good rhythm, but still like you to work on your feet. For you this was a triumph.Arthur Gourounlian gushed: ldquoSo many facial expressions, you seem like you enjoyed it. Dancing wasnrsquot perfect. You were great in hold with Laura. You have improved so much over the weeks.After a short break, it was time for the Bust-A-Move Marathon, giving each couple a second chance to improve their scores.Matthew and Laura were the first couple to be asked to leave the dance floor, earning themselves just one extra point.Despite the heavy public vote that kept Matthew in the earlier rounds, he was up against singer Erica Cody in the dance-off.After the show, Matthew said: ldquoThis has been a rollercoaster,  hours a day, seven days a week. Irsquove grown so much. Laura is so talented and is an amazing person.He thanked Laura for ldquoteaching this rsquo lump with two left feet to dance.The couple were interviewed on RTEacutersquos Ryan Tubridy radio show on Monday morning Matthew admitted that he and Laura had a romantic connection straight away.ldquoShersquos so positive and so nice and kind to people. I just like [that] shersquos got such a love for le that I just resonated with straight away, he said.ldquoShersquos not afraid to go for things which is really admirable. To me I think in todayrsquos society, Laura is the kind of woman that young women should aspire to be like because shersquos strong, shersquos talented, she works hard and she doesnrsquot let anything get in the way of that.Laura said that neither she nor Matthew had expected anything romantic to have happened between them.ldquoIt was just a natural thing that happened between us. We got on so well. It wasnrsquot something I was expecting to happen when I came into the show, she said.ldquoIt just happened that as the weeks went on, we just really clicked as people and we really enjoy each otherrsquos company, so itrsquos just lovely."Matthew and Laura intend to travel to the United States for a well-earned break..prettyPhoto

title: Joseph Ferris Martial Arts students enjoy success at Dundonald Savate Open
story: STUDENTS from Joseph Ferris Martial Arts Academies recently successfully competed in the Dundonald Savate Open.The competition was hosted by Raptur Martial Arts at The Lair in the Inspire Business Park in Dundonald on February .There was a total of  fights and the clubs took  gold wins which was a brilliant achievement.Traditionally when the academies have a national or international competition, Su Joe presents the Jim Fettes Warrior Cup and trophy for the most inspirational junior and senior of the competition.The Jim Fettes Warrior Cup and Trophy is awarded in memory of local man, Jim Fettes.Jim was a great supporter of martial arts training.He believed that it had a positive impact on young people and the community as a whole.For this competition, Finn Carling from the Downpatrick academy was awarded the Junior Warrior Cup and Morgan Sandeman was awarded the Senior Warrior Trophy. Both awards were presented by Ashlinn Fettes, Jimrsquos daughter..prettyPhoto

title: Meeting over future of British Legion branch
story: A MEETING takes place tonight to decide the future of the Royal British Legionrsquos Downpatrick branch.Legion officials have arranged the meeting which takes place in the Parochial Hall at .pm, with news of the event coming just months after Legion officials warned that the future of the annual Remembrance Sunday parade in the town was in doubt due to declining membership.A number of current office-bearers have indicated that they are keen to retire from their current roles, prompting the decision to call next weekrsquos meeting to seenew members are willing to come forward.The branch chairman, Mr Andy Campbell, said the meeting has been called to find out what support there is from local people to get involved in the work of the organisation and ensure that thebranch continues to .ldquoWe are also keen to find out how many of our current members are prepared to carry on. None of us involved with the organisation would want to see it fold, he said.Mr Campbell said the meeting is open to everyone and is encouraging anyone interested in the work of the Royal British Legionrsquos Downpatrick branch to come along.ldquoWe are keen to hear from prospective new members, he said. Tonightrsquos weekrsquos meeting presents us with an opportunity to explore the level of interest in the community as we would like to see the branch continuing to .Ex-servicemen and women who live locally are being encouraged to get involved with the Downpatrick branch which several years ago was forced to close its base at Church Street with the building subsequently sold.Faced with dwindling numbers for the past number of years, the branch has decided to call the open meeting to see what the future holds.Mr Campbell added: ldquoI would encourage anyone with an interest in what we do to come along tonight. We need new members to help keep us going and hope there will be a positive response from the public..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle man receives life saving treatment
story: THE family of Newcastle man Alan McDonald is relieved that he has received the first dose of a potentially lesaving drug in New Zealand.They hope that itrsquos the first tentative step on the  year-oldrsquos road to recovery after having been diagnosed with a le-threatening disease.The -year-old, who lives near Christchurch with his fiancee, learnt over three weeks ago that he has aHUS, an extremely rare and potentially le-threatening disease which affects blood cells and causes damage to vital organs.While available on the NHS in the UK, the drug Eculizumab is not available in New Zealand.Due to the high cost of funding the drug infusions privately, the family launched a GoFundMe appeal last week, raising over pound,.Mr McDonaldrsquos mother Geraldine spoke of her familyrsquos hope for her sonrsquos condition to be stabilised in order for him to be flown back home to complete his treatment.She said: ldquoThe drug Alan needs arrived in New Zealand on Monday and he received his first infusion in the early hours of this morning. It is too early to say how he is responding, however we are hopeful that this is going to be a game changer in his recovery.ldquoAlan still has a long road ahead, but he is buoyed by the support from back home and has asked me to pass on his heartfelt thanks along with our own.Mrs McDonald said that aside from organising the funding appeal, her family felt helpless with her son being so far from home and family members not able to visit him.ldquoIt has been another tough week for Alan, as the medical team in Christchurch worked tirelessly to keep him stable with a series of procedures, including plasma exchange as well as regular dialysis. The treatment so far has already taken a toll on his body and, in Alanrsquos case, it is not having the outcome the medics had hoped for, she said.ldquoWersquove found it really dficult watching Alan go through all of this and not being able to be with him.ldquoThe distance between us back home and him in New Zealand feels even greater and we are desperate to see him again. We applied for visas to enter New Zealand on compassionate grounds three weeks ago but have had no confirmation or updates yet.Borders in New Zealand remain closed to oversea visitors as they prepare for the countryrsquos Covid- peak, but indications show they may reopen in May.Mrs McDonald said that her family has been overwhelmed by the generosity of people and their messages of support, but particularly the messages of hope they have received from people who have recovered from aHUS.ldquoFollowing our campaign to bring Alan home, many people reached out to share their experiences of either having aHUS or caring for a family member suffering from it, she said.ldquoThis has brought us so much comfort, hearing how others, especially those closer to home, have been through a similar situation and are through the other side, living their lives to the full again.The family is now exploring all the options to ensure Alan will have the necessary medical support to enable him to make the long journey home to Newcastle.They are working closely with the British Embassy, New Zealand Health Authorities and the local Health Trust in Northern Ireland in preparation for his arrival on Irish soil..prettyPhoto

title: Preserving our past
story: DOWN County Museum is currently threatened by plans to reduce and downgrade its staffing.Over many years high levels of community engagement and public support have enabled the Museum to build its collections.It is vital that the appropriate resources are deployed not only to care for and interpret the collections but also to maintain and develop links between the collections and the wider community.Take, for example, the museumrsquos photographic archive.Although the D J McNeill collection may be the best known and certainly the most extensive collection of photographs, the museum is responsible for the care and use of many more images.They represent all parts of County Down, of landscapes, towns and villages, inidual and group portraits, people at work, playing sport, historic events and everyday le.Two Men of Mourne was the title of a book published by Down County Museum in , based on photographs in the museum collection.The book highlights the work of two men who had spent many years photographing the Mournes and south Down.Pat Hudson, from Kilkeel, trained as a pharmaceutical chemist, but was a keen photographer ever since his early experience with a box Brownie camera.As an adult he captured the essence of the countryside he loved.His sister, Catherine, described his inquisitive and adventurous spirit which led Pat to leave Ireland in , first to work in an East African pharmacy.Then, after a short time in Jersey, he emigrated to Australia. After a briefto live in the south of England, Pat eventually settled in New Zealand where he spent the rest of his le.Patrsquos landscape photography is stunning and his portraits of local people are without parallel mdash they reveal a strong sense of place, identity and the character of the people.Particularly important is that most of the people have been identied.The photographs were mostly taken in the s and s, but since then the world has changed in many ways. Some of the landscapes may look the same, but buildings have gone, farming le is radically dferent and the fishing industry decimated.Cecil Newman grew up in Belfast, but from a young age enjoyed hiking and youth hostelling. He studied engineering at Queenrsquos University and joined the Royal Engineers during World War II.Whilst working in Berlin after the war to help with the processes of reconstruction, Cecil took some striking photographs of the devastated city. Some of these images were later given to the Berlin City Museum.After the war Cecil ed to work as surveyor for Belfast City Council and later as a planner in the Northern Ireland Civil Service. Amongst the many high-profile projects with which he was involved were the first Newry Area Plan and the Mourne Study. Both these publications included his photographs.During the s he concentrated particularly on aerial photographs. He was a leading member of the Ulster Society for the Preservation of the Countryside and Mournes Advisory Council, often giving talks illustrated with his photographs and slides. After his death the Ulster Society for the Preservation of the Countryside erected a memorial in his honour at Trassey car park in the Mournes.Photographs taken by him which are now in the Down County Museum collection reflect both his work and passion for the Mournes. An outstanding feature of Cecilrsquos photographs is that they were accompanied by date and Ordnance Survey map grid reference mdash what curator could ask for more The importance of these two photographic collections is that they complement each other, in covering the same geographical area, but taken for dferent purposes and at dferent times.The number of images represented is smaller than the DJ McNeill archive so it was possible for the museumrsquos curatorial staff to catalogue them all and the Museum Photographer to digitise them.What remains to be done is adding the images and full information to the Museumrsquos database and more to the website. There are always more jobs to be carried out on the collection.However, using the images effectively, and in the way the Hudson and Newman families, and indeed all other donors, wished, requires wide knowledge of all the collections by experienced and qualied professional staff working with them on a daily basis.The photographic archive is recognised as one of the most important in Ireland and contains a wide range of images, including daguerrotypes, glass negative plates, lantern slides, black and white and colour film, transparencies as well as digital images.Understanding of all the processes involved in their making is essential to how they are cared for and used.Lesley Simpson is secretary of the Friends of Down County Museum and former Keeper of Collections at the museum..prettyPhoto

title: Success at Downpatrick
story: PRIOR to Sundayrsquos Randox Ulster National Handicap Chase meeting at Downpatrick Racecourse, manager Richard Lyttle stated that he was looking forward to welcoming racegoers back to the track for the first time in three years.They certainly turned up with car parks filled to capacity, packed enclosures and long tailbacks on the Ballydugan Road prior to the first race.The Randox Ulster National has been the local tracks major race of the year now for many years and the maximum  runners faced the starter for the three mile four furlong race that sees prize money paid right down to the first six past the post.A bit like the big Aintree race, there was plenty of fallers with two coming down at the very first fence and Envoi Pierji then unseating Donegal jockey Conor Orr, who had ridden Screaming Colours to success for Bill Durkan in the Midlands National at Uttoxeter the previous day.Later in the race there was more fallers at the regulation fence.With two fences to be taken the race involved four runners with the  winner Amaulino travelling like the winner under David McGrath.But this combination then faded, eventually finishing fourth for Co Armagh trainer Keith Watson.The eventual winner in the famous J P McManus Silks proved to be Spades Are Trumps, ridden by Cheltenham winning jockey Mark McDonagh, a lb claimer.Finishing second was Agent Born, ridden by Darragh OrsquoKeefe with Peaches and Cream third.Co Meath trainer Gavin Cromwell, who also had success at Cheltenham, saddled the winner and also the third past the post. SP  ,  ,  .Portstorm, the locally trained favourite was a faller having started at  .The easiest and most popular winner of the day came in the Cosy Roof Bumper Race. Sir Jimmy Mac, with Downpatrick jockey Deckie Lavery in the saddle, was sent into the lead as the starter ped his flag and so well did the leader travel the newcomer was  s clear of the runner-up Rexem, ridden by Ben Harvey with Patrick Mullins only third on Tenzing.Patrick will soon miss seven days due to the suspension he received when getting Billaway up at the post to pip local hope winged leader in the Hunters Chase at Cheltenham.The winner was a first ever runner for owner Mrs Marie Laird of Bright and full marks to her husband Brian, well known in the pony racing world - he won a Dingle Derby - who did all the pre-training with the horse that was bred near Castlewellan by Brenda Cunningham. For Galway trainer Murdoch Kelly this was a welcome success. SP  ,  ,  ,The closest finish of the day came in the ever popular Boardsmill Sires Maiden Hunters Chase over two mile seven furlongs with only a short-head separating the first two past the judge.Handy Headon, with Oran McGill in the saddle, set out to make all in Ray Nicholas colours but after losing a shoe at the second last fence, was overtaken by Armagh winner McCaldinrsquos Faith Loving with Noel McParlan in the saddle.This partnership then lead over the final fence but on the climb to the post started to drt under pressure allow Handy Heaton back into it.However, along the rail came Michaelrsquos Pick to snatch a late victory over Handy Headon second, Faith Loving third, ahead of local Hope Tareeshal, the recent Tyrella winner.The winner is owned by former Westmeath trainer Dot Love and is trained by Ciaran Murphy at her former stables, his brother and twin Joe is a top event rider based outside Killyleagh. For winning rider, Dotrsquos grandson Timmy it was his second success under-rules, his first coming in a bumper back in . SP  ,  ,  fav.It was nice to see Alex Murdoch who rode many Hunter Chase winners at the track in a  year training and riding career, Alex sadly passed away last October at the age of .Featured on the race cardFirst race of the day, The Connollyrsquos Red Mills Maiden Hurdle, saw an awful start, that allowed Dromara owner trainer Neil McCluskeyrsquos I Donrsquot Get It poach a long lead.This lead looked sure to pay off for a long time until the latter stages when Barry Browne got the Oliver McKiernan trained Winding River past to win by three s.Long way back in third came Ben Crawford on The Flier Begley. SP  ,  ,  .There was a stewardrsquos enquiry into the start post race.Following the   and   winners at Down Royal we had another   winner when Jowaya Aoe and Ricky Doyle just get the better of Magic Sea, trained at Banbridge by Sarah Dawson in the closing stages of the WKD Handicap Chase. Back in third came Dferent Strokes. Gerry Keane trains the winner in Co Meath and this was his first National Hunt winner in sometime.The Tote Jackpot is back Handicap Hurdle saw Co Meath trainer John McConnell maintain his good recent track record when Andyrsquos Flame, ridden by Tyrone jockey Simon Torrens, just got up to snatch victory over the Peter Carberry ridden Sight Nor Seen with Dragons Pass third. SP  ,  ,  .Trainer Dermot Weld had another hurdle winner at the track when his Coitor ridden by Darragh OrsquoKeefe won the Toalrsquos Bookmaker race from Clondaw Hollow and Snugsborough Hall. SP  ,  ,  .While there was plenty of Northern owner trained and ridden horses placed at the St Patrickrsquos Day meeting at Down Royal, the only locally owned and trained winner came in the opening bluegrasshorsefeed Maiden Hurdle.The winner here proved to be Billable Grant but going by the SP of   the longest ever priced winner on a local track.Trained at Raffrey by Colin McBratney, the winner was a first winning ride by Gavin Brouder for the local trainer for whom this was a welcome change of fortune. For winning owner Pamela Ballantine it was a first success as an owner in her own colours.Saturday saw the loss of the Co Down Point-to-Point meeting at Loughbrickland following on from the loss of the recent North Down meeting and it has now been confirmed that the end of season meeting at Necarne has also gone.So after the Covid problems and also insurance issues the future looks bleak at present for owners etc with horses ready to run. This Saturday the Portrush meeting is due to take place and I believe the Co Down meeting will not be rearranged..prettyPhoto

title: Tributes are paid to Newcastle man and popular DJ
story: THE family and friends of much-loved U radio presenter and DJ Paul McKenna attended his funeral yesterday.The popular -year-old Newcastle man died last Wednesday at the Northern Ireland Hospice nearly two years after he was first diagnosed with cancer of the oesophagus.Friends from the world of broadcasting, including U presenters Frank Mitchell, Johnny Hero, and Carolyn Stewart and Q Radiorsquos Ibe Sesay, gave on-air emotional tributes to the father of three as the news of his untimely death rocked the entertainment world.He received the cancer diagnosis in June,  when a scan and tests revealed he also had it in his lung.While the cancer was successfully removed, it was followed by a year of chemotherapy treatment.However, Paul was told last year the cancer had ed. While devastated with the news, Paulrsquos we, Emma, said he was determined to beat the disease but only she knew that his condition was terminal.She spoke of his final moments and how his thoughts where of her and his daughters mdash Eimear, Rachel and Evie-Grace.ldquoHe asked me not to let the three girls forget him and he told me how much he loved me. He made me promise I would go to New York next year for my th birthday as thatrsquos where he had planned to take me, Emma told the Sunday Le.Emma described how Paul continued to try and fulfil his busy professional schedule, even going to DJ at an event four weeks ago with a syringe driver around his neck.ldquoPaul would never let anyone down,rsquorsquo said Emma. ldquoHe was still trying to help people.She said her husband only got to spend five nights in their new family home before needing hospice care.Paul, a former student of St Malachyrsquos High School, Castlewellan, started his radio career in Newcastle by helping out a friend with his mobile disco doing weddings. He got his chance to DJ on his own for the first time due to a double booking.He then began to DJ regularly at the Central Park nightclub in his early s, later securing a residency in The Groovy Train at the M Club in Belfast in .Paulrsquos break into radio came in  when he became a presenter with FM in Newry, part of the Q Radio Network, later becoming a breakfast presenter and eventually operations manager.He left in  and worked freelance for three years with Downtown Radio before joining U presenting the Sunday afternoon show in .In , he took on the overnight programme from midnight until am, Monday to Thursday.Paul also was a multi-award winning wedding DJ and played regularly as the recommended DJ for the Hastings Hotel Group.OrsquoHares in Newcastle paid its condolences on social media to Paulrsquos family and friends:: lsquoDJ PK was a resident here for many years and was heavily involved in the success of Central Park and Coast nightclub entertaining generations of party goers here.rsquoAfter a service at Our Lady Of The Assumption Church in Newcastle, Paulrsquos remains left for cremation in Dardistown Crematorium in Dublin..prettyPhoto

title: Washed up munitions a reminder of Murlough’s military history
story: THE news of a controlled explosion on Murlough beach last Thursday might sound shocking.But it isnrsquot the first time that Army bomb disposal experts have detonated a suspected WWII mortar found in County Downrsquos sands.Such ordnance washes up relatively frequently, assumed to have escaped the Beaufort Dyke trench in the Irish Sea, where massive amounts of munitions were dumped after the war mdash including  tons of four-inch mortars.But stray munitions have also been found before in Murloughrsquos sand dunes, reflecting the arearsquos rich wartime history.In fact, Murlough Nature Reserve mdash formerly known as the Dundrum Sandhills mdash has interesting history that extends far beyond WWII.The name itself comes from the old Irish word lsquoMuirbolcrsquo, meaning lsquosea-bagrsquo , and evidence of human activity in the -acre reserve extends back to around  BC.Archaeological digs in the s unearthed multiple signs of burning, hundreds of pottery shards, worked flints and even carbonised hazelnut shells that confirm Neolithic and Bronze Age activity.Much later, Murloughrsquos dunes were important for the Normans. They were used as a commercial rabbit warren when John De Courcy arrived and built Dundrum Castle in .The lucrative trade in rabbit pelts continued for centuries afterwards. Rabbits are still common today, although the population was decimated by the myxomatosis disease in the s.The s was also when the National Trust began managing the habitat on behalf of its owners, the Hill family mdash commonly known as the Marquises of Downshire.The Hill family came to the area in the late th century but had lived in Ireland since the late s, when a young army officer named Moyses Hill, originally from Devon, was posted to Carrickfergus garrison in  to command forces sent by Elizabeth I to subdue the rebellious OrsquoNeill clan and colonise Ireland.Moyses ended up staying in Ireland and marrying the sister of a local clan chief. In , he was granted land at Cromlyn, an area which later took his surname and became known as Hillsborough. His descendants then acquired Murlough in  and began using Murlough Farm as their summer residence.They built Murlough House in , which still stands today at the end of Keel Point mdash at the northern end of the beach. While built to have a spectacular sea view, stormy weather kept breaking the windows, so trees were planted around the house in , and the woodland remains to this day.In , the th Marquis of Downshire, Arthur Hill, sold the surrounding land to the National Trust and then sold the house in . The area became Irelandrsquos first nature reserve in  and remains the most extensive dune heath in Ireland .But prior to being sold to the National Trust, Murlough House and the dunes were a hotbed of military activity ndash particularly during WWII. The house was a base for the US Armyrsquos st Armoured Division and the th Tank Destroyer Battalion.They built several firing ranges in the dunes, including, allegedly, a mortar range. Spare bombers and fighters were also hidden there as Murlough Farm had its own landing strip, called lsquo Satellite Landing Groundrsquo .Murlough beach itself was dotted with anti-aircraft and anti-invasion posts mdash whose rotting remnants are still visible today. They were dug-in when a full-scale German invasion was a threat in the early s.They were part of a counter-invasion strategy that centred on slowing or stopping the enemy at certain locations until other forces could be mustered and deployed. This involved constructing a so-called lsquocoastal crustrsquo along beaches and inland lsquostop-linesrsquo along rivers, canals and high ground.With Northern Ireland being prime invasion territory, a coastal crust was set up from Magilligan in the north-west to Newcastle in the south-east, alongside an inland stop-line along the route of the River Bann. Anti-aircraft landing posts, like those at Murlough, were important in preventing aircraft or boats from landing, but another type of defence was the centrepiece of this strategy: pillboxes.When events at Dunkirk in  sparked invasion panic, the Directorate of Fortications and Works at the War Office was created to construct defensive systems around the UKrsquos beaches. The Royal Engineers and civilian contractors erected over , pillboxes by in a matter of days ndash including on eight of Northern Irelandrsquos beaches.Such structures can still be seen at Magilligan, Portrush and Portstewart. County Down also has intact examples in Bangor, Donaghadee and on the Strangford shore between Comber and Newtownards. Beaches at Minerstown and Tyrella also had multiple pillboxes, as did Murlough. They were spaced to have interlocking arcs of fire, so invaders had little unchallenged space in which to land.One of these pillboxes is still visible in Newcastle, on the beach just below the outdoor swimming pool. The remnants of the other are still visible at the northern end of Murlough, next to the inlet that feeds Dundrum Bay. Yet all that is left are large slabs of reinforced concrete as this pillbox was supposedly destroyed in the early days of the Troubles to prevent it being used to attack the nearby Ballykinlar Army Camp.But these remains are now also under attack from erosion. They are gradually being absorbed by the sea. With this stretch of coastline losing five to ten metres of coastline a year, the remnants of the pillbox, originally built at an elevated height in the dunes, is even starting to be submerged at high tide.What was once a reflection of an indominable spirit is now an unassuming pile of rubble used only as a seat for resting walkers ndash most of whom are unaware of its history. Soon, it will be completely forgotten and the only reminder of this stretch of coastlinersquos rich military history will be the occasional washed-up ordnance.Ben Acheson spent seven years deployed to Afghanistan, including stints as Director of NATOrsquos political team and as Political Adviser to the EU Special Representative. His first book, Wolves Among Men: The Pashtun Tribes in Afghanistan, is due to be published later this year..prettyPhoto
